descr: Serial No. 907-024 Flat-eight air-cooled engine, mounted midship, twin overhead camshafts, fuel injected, 2196cc, 278hp at 8700 rpm
fact1: HEADLINE — A significant evolutionary step.
fact2: FACTS — (1) The 907 featured better aerodynamics and balance over the 910/6, and an 8-cyl. Type 771 engine. (2) This car won the 12 Hours of Sebring in 1968 by more than ten laps over its sister car.
fact3: STORIES — This car was the last addition to the Porsche gallery, filling a hole in the progression of late-60s racers. It had been raced by a rich young Bolivian in 1969-70 before being tucked away for four decades. Restoration included 1,000 hours of body work to remove 400 pounds of added fiberglass.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — Major changes from the 910/6: Better aerodynamics (coefficient of drag of 0.27); driver position moved to right side for better balance and visibility on clockwise road courses; and obsessive weight reduction (e.g. reduced number of coils in springs from 910/6).
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — (1) This was the first Porsche to exceed 300 kph (186 mph). (2) The car features a “cooling box” in the nose where ice was put for cold-air hosing to the driver, but the ice was a weight penalty so it was never used in a race.

descr: 4 cyl inline pushrod 633cc, 21.2hp @ 4,500 rpm , 1,543 lb, 4 spd manual Trans, 4/5 or 6 pass, Top Speed 57mph
fact1: HEADLINE — The first mini-van.
fact2: FACTS — In answer to the baby-boom of post-WWII Italy, Fiat based this multi-purpose vehicle on the their 600 sedan. It came in three factory versions: A four-seat taxi, with front seat as luggage shelf, a 4 to 5 passenger “camper” with back seats folding to a bed, and the six-seat mini-van such as this one. Nearly 240,000 were built from 1956 through 1966.
fact3: STORIES — The Miles Collier Collection’s car had endured much time with rodents living inside, so a complete and faithful in-house restoration was in order. The only changes made to the car were concessions to modern traffic — a 1050 cc Fiat Abarth motor has triple the power over the car’s original 767 cc unit, and the brakes are now dual-circuit. The original cost of the car in 1960 was $1,198 (743,000 lire), and a Revs technician figured that around $100,000 was spent on the restoration. The Multipla now promotes Revs at a wide range of public events.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — Dante Giacosa’s people-mover ended up being under 1400 lbs in weight and sat on just a 79-inch wheelbase, with the driver’s seat set far forward over the front suspension. This had the benefit of quick steering and great agility. But performance of the first models was limited by a 25 hp motor, so that 0-to-50 took 40 seconds.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — Fiat resurrected the Multipla nameplate from 1998 to 2012, as a compact multi-purpose vehicle that came to be regarded as one of the ugliest cars ever made.

descr: Serial No. 23-S-28 Four-cylinder in-line engine, dual overhead camshafts
fact1: HEADLINE — A parts bin giant killer.
fact2: FACTS — The second-lightest car at Revs (1,100 lbs), this sports racer sprang from parts out of two of Lotus’ Formula Junior single-seaters, and continued Colin Chapman’s mantra of “adding more lightness”. Around 130 were built, driven to much success, especially in the hands of such greats as Jim Clark.
fact3: STORIES — This car was raced extensively in SCCA regional and national racing, and rebuilt after a heavy accident when it was melded with another wrecked 23. After trading hands several times it ended up with Gerry Strickfaden, who restored and upgraded it in 2013 to current vintage racing standards. Strickfaden then donated it to Revs, which fields it in historic events to demonstrate Chapman’s genius.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — The Lotus 23 adopted the suspension and disc brakes of its Formula Junior siblings, set on a space frame and fiberglass body. At just over 1000 lb in weight and with great balance, the original 1100 cc pushrod motor provided 100 hp. A 1594 cc DOHC with dual Weber carbs now provides 170 hp.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — Some drivers have remarked that the car seems smaller when viewed from the outside than it does from the cockpit, where it’s said to be surprisingly roomy.

descr: Serial No. 593 Two-cylinder 1189cc
fact1: Early car’s “Panhard System” set the convention to follow of front engine/rear drive layout.
fact2: Gottlieb Daimler-designed engine, built under license by Panhard et Levassor in France.
fact3: Vaporous alcohol fuel is ignited at a pair of Bunsen burners, with “hot tube” ignition running heat down to the narrow-Vee twin cylinders; start-up takes over 15 minutes.
fact4: 3.5 HP with no throttle and three (exposed) gears for a top speed of 10 mph.
fact5: 1895 Paris-Bordeaux-Paris winner, 745 miles in 49 hours. Over half a century later it won the 1956 London-Brighton Run, 60 miles carrying 6 people.
fact6: This oldest car in the Miles Collier Collection is in virtually original condition and is still exercised.

descr: Serial No. 2207 Six-cylinder in-line engine, single overhead camshaft, 7982 cc, 144 hp at 2500 rpm.
fact1: Example of the way luxury automobiles were sold - custom coach sold separately.
fact2: One of the most advanced cars of its time.
fact3: Pioneered use of aluminum engine parts.
fact4: Chassis shows extremely high quality workmanship and attention to detail.
fact5: Its 6 cylinder engine derived from V8 engine developed by Birgit for WWI aircraft (Spad S.XII and the S.XIII)
fact6: Patented mechanical-servo brakes on all four wheels was a first, licensed to others.

descr: Serial No. 300-128 Flat Six Cylinder, Air Cooled, Single Overhead Cam, 1991cc, 130HP @ 6100RPM's
fact1: HEADLINE — The iconic replacement to the 356 model.
fact2: FACTS — This car was the 128th made of the new model, and 1 of 2 sent to the US in late 1964 for demonstration/promotion at the Brundage Motors (later Brumos) dealership in Jacksonville.
fact3: STORIES — After a year and 30,000 demo miles at Brundage, Atlanta VW dealer Jack Ryan bought the car off their showroom floor. Despite a used motor and no performance parts yet available for a new model, the street car was entered in the 1966 24 Hours of Daytona. The factory Porsche team feared the new and unproven model would fail and embarrass the company — until it placed 16th overall and won its class, the first win anywhere for a 911.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — This was Butzi Porsche’s only other design project lead. It carried over  design cues from the 356C with significant new features, including McPherson strut suspension, rack-and-pinion steering and a flat 6-cylinder engine.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — This was Porsche design project 901, but became “911” after Peugeot touted their trademark for production street cars of three-number names with a zero in the middle. Unfortunately, “901” marketing materials had already been prepared and released, test drives published, and 84 cars built before Peugeot’s lawyers called.[Note the exhibit text error on car’s weight: Should be 2,300+ lbs, not 1,590.]

descr: Serial No. 54148 Six-cylinder in-line engine, single overhead camshaft, 7272 cc, 95 hp at 1800 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — A factory team racer with “another past”.
fact2: FACTS — The six cylinder engine is inspired from an aero design, and is cast in 3 blocks of 2 cylinders, with two updraft carburetors.
fact3: STORIES — Mercedes-Benz archives helped prove to Revs volunteers Paul Kiersten and Eric Judson that this is actually a 1921 Mercedes Sport model rather than the ‘23 Targa Florio it was thought to be by previous owner, Briggs Cunningham.
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — Car went from a two-seat racer to a four-seat tourer, then to a two-seat Targa Florio-style configuration around 1947.
fact5: INSIGHT - Daimler capitalized on the racing success of customer (and later board member) Emil Jellinek, who commissioned three-dozen cars and named them after his beloved daughter, Mercedes. Later he had his name legally changed to add the Mercedes name.

descr: Serial No. 2110 Four-cylinder in-line engine, 3620 cc (220.9 cubic inches), 64 hp at 2300 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — One of the first sports cars.
fact2: FACTS — Monoblock engine has a camshaft on each side of the crankshaft, one for intake and one for exhaust, with open-spring push rods and side poppet valves. Although no cylinder head, valves had threaded access ports.
fact3: STORIES — Fragile wire wheels showed quality & good European roads.
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — Original body replaced by this smaller “voiturette”, one of King Alfonzo’s favorite styles. Restored in-house at Revs.
fact5: INSIGHT — Acetylene-fueled headlamps were added later, fed by canister in running board box.

descr: Serial No. 3030 Eight cylinder in-line engine, double overhead camshafts, twin Roots-type superchargers 2991 cc, 360 hp at 6300 rpm
fact1: HEADLINE — In Europe, the competition was too good; in America, these were a hit.
fact2: FACTS — This car, chassis number 3030, finished 10th in the 1940 Indy 500. It ran at Indy three more times after WWII, and placed second in the 1949 Pikes Peak Hillclimb. Chassis 3031 was the Indy 500 pole-sitter (finishing 26th) in 1941 and won Pikes Peak in 1946 and ‘47. Chassis 3032 won the Indy 500 in 1939 and ‘40 for “Umbrella” Mike Boyle, with Wilbur Shaw behind the wheel; it finished 3rd in 1946 and ‘47, and 4th in ‘48.
fact3: STORIES — Cars 3030 and 3031 were entered by Lucy O’Reilly Schell for the 1940 Indianapolis 500, to drum up American support for France on the eve of WWII. An expatriate American heiress living in Paris, Lucy had been one of the more successful female racers in Europe in the 20s, and married to another driver. After hanging up her helmet, she turned to owning and commissioning race cars.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — The engine used a fixed cylinder head, or “testa fissa” — the TF in the car’s designation. With no head gasket, this allowed for higher compression.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — (1) The photo above car 3030 shows our car as it raced at Indy in 1940, with Grand Prix driver Rene Dreyfus at the wheel. However, it ran the race with Dreyfus and Rene Le Begue (“La-BECK”) splitting the driving, because Dreyfus threw a rod in practice in 3030 and the motor from Le Begue’s 3031 was used. That motor is still in the car. (2) Lucy O’Reilly Schell sent the cars to Indy with Le Mans winner Luigi Chinnetti (“KEH-netti”) serving as chief mechanic. He stayed in the States and became Enzo Ferrari’s presence in America after the War.

descr: Serial No. 718-041 Flat-four air-cooled engine, mounted midship, twin overhead camshafts, 1697 cc, 170 hp at 7800 rpm
fact1: HEADLINE — The Porsche that fully got Enzo Ferrari’s attention.
fact2: FACTS — Rules changes led to enough of a modification to the 718 to warrant a name change from the RSK to the RS-60, with 19 made.
fact3: STORIES — Jo Bonnier and Hans Hermann took this car to the overall win at the 1960 Targa Florio, one of Porsche’s first big wins. RS-60s won seven other 1960 World Sportscar Championship races, including Sebring, but lost the 1960 manufacturer’s championship to Ferrari in a tie-break.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — The FIA’s “road-worthiness” rule changes forced a high windscreen, folding top and rear “luggage” space be added to the car — but the new rules also allowed for an increase in engine displacement over the previous 718 RSK’s 1,498cc. Other changes included a wider space frame chassis and trailing arms added to the wishbone rear suspension.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — While Hans Hermann co-drove this car to win gold at the 1960 Targa Florio, he also scored a bronze by co-driving the third place RS-60.

descr: Serial No. 718 048: Flat-eight air-cooled engine, mounted midship, twin overhead camshafts, 1982 cc, 210 hp at 8200 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — A test bed for the development of Porsche’s 8-cylinder F1 engine.
fact2: FACTS — The 1961 718 was designated the RS-61. This was 1 of 2 (of 17 total RS-61s) that had a longer wheelbase for the flat 8 engine.
fact3: STORIES — Bob Holbert won the SCCA championship in this car in 1961 and ‘62. He received this car as the replacement for a wrecked regular-length RS chassis, as the factory had nothing else available.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — Holbert mounted a spare Fuhrmann 4-cam in this longer chassis to complete the 1961 SCCA season. An original 8-cylinder factory motor has been reinstalled.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — This was the very last of the Porsche aluminum-bodied racers.

descr: Serial No. 84461: Flat-four air-cooled engine, rear mounted, twin overhead camshafts, 1587 cc, 160+ hp at 7500 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — A stripped and lightened variant for select amateur racing clients.
fact2: FACTS — Legendary US road racer Bruce Jennings campaigned three of these cars into the early ‘60s in SCCA racing. This was Jennings’ favorite of the three, and he and “Pup” Pupilidy drove it to a record 67 wins over eight years.
fact3: STORIES — By 1954 a third of all 356 model sales were in the US, prompting US distributor Max Hoffman to urge Porsche to offer a cabriolet variation that could attract buyers of roadsters like the Jaguar XK120.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — The Speedster version of the cabriolet 356 had a lower windshield, bucket seats and sliding side curtains; selling for $3,000 it became instant hit, especially in California. Adding the Fuhrmann 4-cam race engine created the Carrera, good for 120 mph top speed with 0-60 in 11 seconds. Less than 150 Carrera coupes and lighter Speedsters were built, with a price tag of $6,000 each.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — Jennings dubbed the car “Mehitabel” after an alley cat featured in columns by Don Marquis in the New York Evening Sun.

descr: Serial No. 70/069: Flat four air-cooled engine, mounted midship, twin overhead camshafts, 1679 cc, 183 hp.
fact1: HEADLINE — Another collaboration from Porsche’s preoccupation with F1.
fact2: FACTS — Elva was a British sports racer manufacturer. This was offered in the US as the replacement to the six-year run of the 718, with 19 made.
fact3: STORIES — Revs volunteer Bill Wuesthoff and Augie Pabst won the USRRC Road America 500 in another Elva Porsche; this car was campaigned by Joe Pendergast.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — Elva took the small Mark VII, with a tubular frame and fiberglass body, and redesigned the rear to accept the Fuhrmann four-cam Porsche engine.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — (1) At a total of 975 pounds, it is the lightest car in the collection. (2) The name Elva is from the French phrase elle va (“she goes”).

descr: Serial No. 906125: Flat-six air-cooled engine, mounted midship, single overhead camshaft, 1991 cc, 210 hp at 8000 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — The start of the Ferdinand Piëch design era.
fact2: FACTS — The 906 was developed in response to success of Ferrari Dino 196 in the early 60s. With a reduction in homologation from 100 to 50 cars, Piëch abandons the “outdated”  904 for this new one. Sister cars to this finished 4th through 7th behind the Ford GT40s at the 1966 Le Mans. A total of 62 were made, 52 of them with the 2-liter motor, at $11,000 each.
fact3: STORIES — Ferry’s son “Butzi” was ousted from head of design by cousin Ferdinand “Burli” Piëch, who hired 200 engineers focused on producing cars to win Le Mans.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — (1) This marked a transition to the 6-cylinder Type 901/20 race engines, and a return to a tube frame, given reduced homologation requirements and issues repairing the 904’s box frame. Its high wheel arches were dictated by the use of surplus 904 15 in. 5-bolt wheels, brakes and suspensions. (2) This was the first Porsche design to be wind-tunnel tested.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — (1) The 906 was the last truly road-worthy Porsche racer (though no longer available through dealerships). (2) This car appeared on screen, playing a key role in season 2, episode 16 of the ‘80s TV series Miami Vice.

descr: Serial No. 550 032: Flat-four air-cooled engine, mounted midship, twin overhead camshafts, 1498 cc, 150 hp at 8200 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — A race driver’s personal project.
fact2: FACTS — Ferrari F1 driver Jean Behra dreamed up this one-off concept for a Formula 2 racer, based on the mechanicals of the 718 RSK Porsche and built with the aid of the factory. Barely completed in Spring of 1959, it was eligible for and entered in the Monaco Grand Prix, where Maria Theresa DeFillipis failed to qualify. After that it was competitive in several F2 races, driven by Hans Hermann and Behra. The car was bought by the American Camorodi team, where it ran in two F1 races in 1960 with Maston Gregory and Fred Gamble.
fact3: STORIES — Behra was a driver for Ferrari’s F1 team, but had a strained relationship with Enzo, made worse after Behra’s little Porsche bested the Ferrari factory cars in F2 races. Behra was fired from his F1 seat mid-1959, and was set to run this car in the F1 race at Avus but was was killed in an RSK in the warmup F2 race.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — The 1.5 liter Fuhrmann four-cam engine was modified and fitted with larger carburetors, resulting in the 150 bhp Type 547/2. A Watt’s-linkage of two radius rods replaced the single trailing arm, better controlling the angle of the drive wheels during travel.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — 1n 1962, Dan Gurney won the French GP in a Porsche factory F1 car reminiscent of Behra’s 1958 F2 machine.

descr: Serial No. 1001: Flat-four air-cooled engine, rear-mounted, twin overhead camshafts, 1587 cc, 135 hp at 6500 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — German engineering with Italian flair.
fact2: FACTS — By 1960, Porsche’s preoccupation with its F1 program meant less attention and resources to develop a new sports racer. Carlo Abarth called in to run the project in Italy.
fact3: STORIES — Aerodynamics and lightening allowed top speed of 138, a class win at 1960 and a Le Mans, where it took on water from poor door seals when driven in near-constant rain.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — This was the first of 20 lightweight aluminum bodies styled by Franco Scaglioni and built by Rocco Motto. This was a 356 platform that was chopped, shortened and narrowed by 5 inches each way. A Type 692 engine was used — a larger and a more developed version of the original 547 four-cam family.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — This was Mr. Collier’s second collection acquisition, after the red 904 Carrera GTS.

descr: Serial No. 917 028 Flat-twelve air-cooled engine, mounted midship, twin overhead camshafts, fuel injected, 4494 cc, 580 hp at 8400 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — The first foray into eventual dominance of the Can-Am series.
fact2: FACTS — Despite early domination of the Can-Am series by McLarens (with 10% more hp) this car was relatively successful “out of the box”, finishing 4th in the 1969 championship. When the flat-12 engine later was turbocharged for up to 1,100 hp, Mark Donohue went on to dominate the Can-Am series by 1972 in the 917/30.
fact3: STORIES — “Burli” Piëch was persuaded to build this for Can-Am after Volkswagen of America agreed to sponsor the program (as “Porsche-Audi – PA”) and driver Jo Siffert added his voice.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — The car’s body was inspired by the 908/02 “Flunder”.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — Porsche was finishing development of a 16 cylinder engine when the Can-Am rules were changed for 1974, virtually ending the series.

descr: Serial No. 9140432542 Flat-six air-cooled engine, mounted midship, single overhead camshaft, 1991 cc, 210 hp at 8000 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — A joint venture between Porsche and Volkswagen.
fact2: FACTS — This 914/6 GT represented a race-prepped version, with 32 built. The GT debuted at 1970 Le Mans where it won class and finished 6th overall behind 917s and Ferraris.
fact3: STORIES — The car was something of a failure in Europe, with the 4-cylinder version seen as  underpowered when sold at Porsche dealers or expensive at VW dealers. But, in the US both versions sold as Porsches at Porsche dealers, becoming a hot seller with over 118,000 sold with the “entry-level” 4-cyl. engine, and 3,300 sold with the robust 6-cyl.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — Porsche and VW developed a model that both could market,  satisfying the needs to replace Porsche’s 4-cyl. 912 and VW’s Karmann-Ghia. The 914 shared a body across both companies, with brand-specific engines (the 4-cyl. for VW and the 6-cyl. for Porsche).
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — Miles Collier raced this car in the early 1980s.

descr: Serial No. 11899005R Flat-six air-cooled engine, rear mounted, single overhead camshaft, 1991 cc, 210 hp at 8000 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — They tried a “fast one” with this fast one.
fact2: FACTS — The racing success of the early 911 spurred an attempt to produce a thinly-veiled prototype version and still call it a production 911.  The sanctioning body didn’t buy it. The 23 911Rs already built had to race in non-production classes or as rally cars. And, as a lightweight with 50 more horsepower, the 911R excelled in rally events. This car won the Tour de France and Tour de Corse rallies in 1969 with Gerard Larrousse piloting.
fact3: STORIES — (1) The 911R was green-lighted only because it appealed to the lightness mantra of the new head of design, Ferdinand (“Burli”) Piëch, who was an aeronautical engineer by training. (2) On seeing his former car at Revs for the first time, Larrousse was said to have been upset to see his name misspelled on the door; he was told that the car was merely returned to the state seen in the 1969 photo above the car, featuring the missing “R”.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — Up to 300 pounds less weight was achieved: Fiberglass body panels, thinner windshield, plastic windows, plastic door handles, straps to raise windows and fewer dash instruments. The rear fenders were slightly flared to fit wider rear tires, and this became a 911 styling convention.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — This car was used in the filming of Steve McQueen’s film Le Mans.

descr: Serial No. 910 007 Flat-six air-cooled engine, single overhead camshaft, fuel injected, 1991 cc, 220 hp at 8000 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — A significant improvement on the 906.
fact2: FACTS — This car won the “home soil” 1967 Nürburgring 1000km, a significant point of pride for Porsche.
fact3: STORIES — Ferdinand Piëch’s laser-focus on lightness led to replacing the 906’s 5-lug 15” wheels with center-hub 13” magnesium wheels, and even thinner plexiglas bodies.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — The suspension was improved from the 906, with longitudinal thrust struts in the rear, thrust struts and wishbones in the front, and coil-over springs and dampers. The flat-six motor added dual coil transistor ignition, with Bosch fuel injection below throttle slides.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — Less than 30 were built. Shorter and lighter than the preceding 906, this made for better competition with the Ford GT40 and Ferrari prototypes in WSC racing.

descr: Serial No. 908 025: Flat-eight air-cooled engine, mounted midship, twin overhead camshafts, fuel-injected, 2997 cc, 350 hp at 8400 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — A successful but unstable “placeholder”.
fact2: FACTS — Derived from the 907 to compete in the 3-liter WSC class in 1968, and carried on in ’69 while the 917 suffered development problems. This car won the 1969 1000km at Spa and placed 2nd at Monza. A sister car finished 2nd at Le Mans that year, losing to a GT40 by only 400 feet.
fact3: STORIES — The long, tapered body had low drag for high-speed courses such as Spa Francorchamps, Monza, Le Mans, but was highly unstable past 170 mph. Ailerons, actuated by suspension loading, were added to try to calm the car’s tendency to “fly” at high speed.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — The new 8-cyl. engine had a less complex design than the 907’s, to last in long races.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — LH stood for Langheck (German for “long-tail”)

descr: Serial No. 908/03 013: Flat-eight air-cooled engine, mounted midship, twin overhead camshafts, fuel-injected, 2997 cc, 360 hp at 8400 rpm
fact1: HEADLINE — Successful far beyond its years, and intent.
fact2: FACTS — A true mid-engine design, inspired by Porsche’s 909 hillclimb racer. The 908/03 car was designed for intricate circuits like Targa Florio and Nürburgring.
fact3: STORIES — Despite the 908/03 being designed for tight courses, this car ran Le Mans four times, placing 5th overall in 1974. It was successfully campaigned into the 1980s.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — The motor is almost in the center of the stubby car, for a low polar moment of rotation and optimum handling on twisty courses. Only 75 lbs. of car’s weight was its aluminum frame and plastic body. Extensive use was made of titanium. What weight there is has a 45:55 distribution, thanks to placing the 5-speed transmission ahead of the differential and pushing the motor towards the front.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — The driver sits so far forward that the pedals are ahead of the wheels.

descr: Serial No. 904 046 Two liter (1966cc), twin overhead camshaft, Flat four, air cooled engine mounted midship, 180 hp at 7000rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — A radical departure for Porsche sports racing.
fact2: FACTS — This was the successor to the 718 RSK, and marked Porsche’s return to focusing on sports car racing after its ill-fated foray in Formula One. At least 104 were built for homologation as a production class racer, with half intended as street cars at a cost of $7,000. It was the last Porsche racer you could buy from a dealership.
fact3: STORIES — (1) In street guise, the 904 was called the Carrera GTS, given the trademark Peugeot had on passenger car number-names with zeros in the middle. But, since Peugeot was only concerned with passenger cars, the race-designated versions of this car could be called 904s. There wasn’t much difference between the two designations. (2) While labeled as a street car, this car raced the Targa Florio and the Nurburgring 1000K in 1964.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — The design was headed up by Dr. Porsche’s grandson/Ferry’s son “Butzi” while in his late 20s. The traditional Porsche tube frame design was ditched in favor of a more production-friendly steel perimeter box frame with a fiberglass body bonded on. It was the last Porsche to use the fabled Fuhrmann 4-cam motor.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — The idea for Porsche’s crest logo came from US distributor Max Hoffman, to convey the company’s roots. The horse represents Stuttgart’s city seal and it’s origin as a horse-breeding capitol.

descr: Serial No. 904 018 1966cc twin overhead camshaft flat-four, air-cooled engine mounted midship, 180 hp at 7000 rpm
fact1: HEADLINE — Porsche’s return to focusing on sports car racing.
fact2: FACTS — This was the successor to the long-in-the tooth 718s and 355B Carreras that had been carrying the banner in sports car racing while Porsche was preoccupied in Formula 1 and developing the 911.
fact3: STORIES — Briggs Cunningham owned and drove this in the 12 Hours of Sebring, to a class win in 1964 (9th overall), ‘65 (20th) and ‘66 (DNF), his last professional race.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — 904 design was headed up by Dr. Porsche’s grandson/Ferry’s son “Butzi” while in his late 20s. Previous tube frame design was ditched for a quicker-to-produce steel perimeter box frame, with sheet metal underbody pulled up to meet a fiberglass body. Briggs designed a different fiberglass tail for this car, as the early vendor-supplied bodies used crack-prone sprayed chopped-fiber technology with significant weight variations. This was the first Porsche with double-wishbone and coil-over shocks front and rear, and the last Porsche to use the Type 547 Fuhrmann 4-cam engine, after a decade of fabrication (of less than 2,000 units).
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — (1) This was the last time you could buy a race car off a Porsche showroom floor (for $7,425 in 1964). (2) At least 104 were built for homologation to allow racer versions to run in production car GT class. (3) In racing form, these could be called 904s, as Peugeot’s issue with having a zero in the middle of a number-name had to do only with street cars. (4) Top speed was 160, and difficult to drive.

descr: Serial No. 550A-0139 Flat-four, air-cooled engine, mounted midship, twin overhead camshafts, 1498 cc, 135 hp at 7200 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — A “cradle” for a generation of great drivers.
fact2: FACTS — This was an evolutionary step from the 550, moving from a ladder to space frame, and from a pushrod engine to the complex Fuhrmann four-cam.
fact3: STORIES — One 550A won the 1956 Targa Florio outright for Porsche’s first win in international competition, and enhancing the “Giant Killer” mystique.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — The suspension was modified and improved from the 550, but still had swing axles.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — (1) Forty of these racers were produced, and could be purchased from Porsche dealerships. (2) Actor James Dean was famously killed in a similar-looking Spyder, but that was a 550 model that still had a ladder frame. (3) This car was driven by Briggs Cunningham and Denise McCluggage.

descr: Serial No. 225007A: Eight-cylinder L-head in-line engine, nine main bearings, 384 cubic inches, 106 hp at 3200 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — A sporty aberration from a company known for big touring cars and stately convertibles.
fact2: FACTS — This was one of 4 prototype test mules built to establish what would become the 626 Speedster (1929-30).
fact3: STORIES — The brainchild of Packard chief engineer Jesse Vincent who was something of a “speed freak”. Vincent took Yale-bound Briggs Cunningham for a 100 mph test track drive - in the snow - that sold BSC.
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — After buying car, Briggs replaced 4-seat body with a version of the Packard speed record car that inspired Cunningham Cars of Rochester.
fact5: INSIGHT — Car was tested extensively on Yale dynamometer for the 2 years BSC was an engineering student there.

descr: Serial No. 1858 4-cyl, 3619 cc, 40-45 HP, HP to WT Ratio: 39.2, Weight: 1764 pounds
fact1: HEADLINE — An early brand known for meticulous engineering, quality, performance and style.
fact2: FACTS — Preserved after 82 years in the same family. This is one of seven of the long wheelbase models that survive, and it’s in virtually original and running condition. Electric system and instrument panel were improvements added later.
fact3: STORIES — This car was built in France, where the factory moved for better labor contracts and importing, but spent most of its time in Spain. Vintage car expert Eddie Berrisford found “witness marks” in rear floor for apparent machine gun mounts (perhaps this participated in the Spanish Civil War?).
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — The long-wheelbase touring design was not necessarily a sports car, but the sporting underpinnings are there.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — Co-owner and Swiss engineer Marc Birkgit designed dozens of cars (including EVs and a hybrid), as well as aviation motors, from 1905 to 1938. He started as a watchmaker.

descr: Serial No. 1449 Four-cylinder in-line engine, T-head, 597 cubic inches, 60 hp at 1200 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — The “American Mercedes”
fact2: FACTS — Was high-status, fast (90 mph) and expensive ($4,500 just for chassis). Extremely well-built for the terrible US roads (note the caisson wheels).
fact3: STORIES — Company started by New York City Mercedes importers who couldn’t sell Daimler’s cars due to high tariffs. Coincidently, Simplex was the name of the latest Mercedes model.
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — Originally owned by Barron Gift Collier, then sold to Briggs Cunningham, who restored and revised it based on Simplex company catalogues and including all possible options.
fact5: INSIGHT — This car was said to have been present at the opening of the Tamiami Trail in 1928, the construction of which had been completed by Barron Collier when the State ran out of funds.

descr: Serial No. 3003 (356/2 055) Flat-four, air-cooled pushrod VW-type engine, rear-mounted, Porsche–designed cylinder heads, 1498 cc, 72 hp at 5000 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — A competition version of the first Porsche.
fact2: FACTS — The project was started by “Ferry” Porsche in 1947 while his father, Dr. Ferdinand Porsche, was still imprisoned in France. The first fifty 356s were built from 1948-49 in a converted sawmill in Gmünd (“Geh-MUNDT”) Austria. Production then moved in 1950 to rented Reutter coach works space in Stuttgart.
fact3: STORIES — Two of the Gmünd-style 356SLs were entered in the 1951 Le Mans and, while one was damaged in a pre-race crash, the other took a class win and 19th overall.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — Erwin Komenda designed the bodies, of hand-hammered aluminum for the cars made in the Gmünd sawmill. The Stuttgart factory produced steel bodied cars, but also a few SL (super light) aluminum bodied racing 356s. The rear-mounted, air-cooled VW-type pushrod motor utilized Porsche-designed cylinder heads.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — In 1951 this car ran the Montlhéy track for 72 straight hours, setting a record by averaging 94.66 mph, then was driven directly to the Paris Auto Show for display in its racing condition. This car received a recent multi-year restoration, and is shown in livery of Liege-Rome-Liege rally in which it won its class and 3rd overall.

descr: Serial No. 4959 Eight‐cylinder in‐line engine, single overhead camshaft, three valves per cylinder (two inlet, one outlet), Roots type supercharger 2261 cc (138 cubic inches), 140 hp at 5000 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — One of the most dominant race cars ever.
fact2: FACTS — Type 35s are credited with over 2,000 race wins. This car was one of four factory entries for Targa Florio in 1930. As pictured in the exhibit photo, it placed 2nd with Louis Chiron (“Lou-WEE SHA-Rhawn”) at the wheel. Chiron would later have a Bugatti supercar named in his honor.
fact3: STORIES — While this car did race in the Pau region of France pre-WWII, it ended up in the UK, where it was discovered stripped and in pieces in a garage. Part of a family dispute over an estate, it had been forgotten until the early 2000s.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — The SOHC motor has three valves per cylinder — two intake, one exhaust.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — This car represents conservation and preservation personified, where the originality of this car — with “no false patination” — is prized.

descr: Modified Flat four 2.6 Liter Type 4, 207 Hp, 190+ lb/ft torque
fact1: HEADLINE — The car that other companies shunned.
fact2: FACTS — Ferdinand Porsche won a 1934 design competition to create a “People’s Car” for Hitler’s Third Reich. Porsche’s project #60, Hitler named it the KdF-Wagen, for Kraft durch Freude Wagen (“Strength Through Joy Car”). Limited production began in 1938, but halted with the start of WWII after a few hundred had been produced.
fact3: STORIES — …After WWII, Wolfsburg was in the jurisdiction of British occupying forces. The damaged VW factory and this project was offered up to other carmakers, with no takers. The head of the occupying forces, Major Ivan Hirst, was a “car-guy” who was intent on starting up production of the Beetle to get people working again. The factory was repaired, locals hired, and production of the Beetle slowly ramped up, starting in late 1945. The car that no one wanted ended up with a 65-year production run and nearly 22 million built.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — The original parameters called for a car to carry four passengers at 100 Km/h. An air-cooled motor for reliability, with a steel body over a pressed steel pan and Y-shaped backbone.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — At first glance this appears to be an innocuous Beetle in stock VW Prairie Beige. However, it’s original 36 hp motor has been replaced with a modified 2.6 flat-four Type 4 motor delivering over 200 hp and 190 lbs of foot-torque. It’s lightened with aluminum body panels, and Porsche suspension parts from a 718 Spyder and 911, and Carrera GT brakes help keep it glued to the road — or track. Top speed is at least 120 mph, with a 0-60 time of five seconds. The “hot rodding” was performed by the California shop of Troutman and Barnes, who had done such notable American racing builds as the first Chaparrals and the Scarabs.

descr: Serial No. OE 305 Four-cylinder in-line pushrod engine, 4224 cc, 120+ hp at 3500 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — An eye-catching “hot rodded” European touring car.
fact2: FACTS — One of the last built of this model, spanning 596 cars over 14 years.
fact3: STORIES — Originally owned (in blue) by a young Henry B. DuPont, it was acquired after WWII by Col. George Felton, who hot-rodded it…
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — …Felton beefed up the engine, brakes and suspension, and replaced the running boards with cycle fenders. He also stripped the paint down to polished aluminum (hence “Quicksilver”).
fact5: INSIGHT — (1) Raced in first post-WWII road race at Watkins Glen GP in 1948 (DNF); 9th in ’49 (as pictured in exhibit photo). This was two decades after the car was built. (2) Tonneau cover over the back seat was used for ‘streamlining”.

descr: Serial No. E311 Four-cylinder in-line side valve engine, 4526 cc, 90 hp at 2800 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — A touring car from the company that created what’s considered to be the very first sports car (the 1910 Prince Henry).
fact2: FACTS — Model designation referred to “taxable” horsepower, derived from a formula of actual horsepower, piston bore and cylinder count.
fact3: STORIES — Despite early use of front-wheel (drum) brakes, the car was difficult to stop; helped give rise to the “downshift first, brake as a last resort” practice of driving in Britain.
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — A direct competitor with Bentley’s 3-Liter, and a popular gentleman’s hill-climb car once stripped of its unnecessary bits (windscreen, fenders, top…).
fact5: INSIGHT — Velox is Latin for “swift or fleet”, and by the time Miles Collier bought the car in 2000 as a bookend to Quicksilver, it had been actively enjoyed by several enthusiasts down through the years.

descr: Serial No. 4003 HG Six-cylinder in-line engine, twin overhead camshafts, seven main bearings, dry sump lubrication, 2916 cc, 90 hp at 3800 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — A wolf in sheep’s clothing.
fact2: FACTS — This stylish tourer was capable of 90 mph thanks to an exotic race car motor. It was the first use of a double overhead cam engine in a production car. Conceived to challenge Bentley’s dominance, the car’s price tag ($6,750) and complex engineering during the Depression limited the customer pool, so that only 315 were built.
fact3: STORIES — The company had a complicated history. The first cars were English and dated to 1899. A French designer came in in 1909, production ramped up, and racing versions began to spread acclaim. After payments for WWI support efforts dried up and the founder died, the company foundered in the 20s. At this time a convergence of British offshoots of the Darracq and Talbot companies tied together with Sunbeam, to become STD Motors. This led to the headiest days for the company, including signature Grand Prix wins and land speed records. With the Depression came the dissolution of STD, with part of the company going on to become Talbot-Lago, which went on to its own fame.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — Dry-sump lubrication and non-detachable heads were among applications of racing features in a street car. The car sat long and low for its day, accentuated by cantilevered rear leaf springs. Enhancing the racing aesthetic of the car was the replacement of front wing fenders with cycle fenders that turned with the wheels. This particular car is off having a few inaccuracies addressed.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — This car’s motor was built in 1926, the chassis in ‘27, assembly was in ‘28, and it wasn’t sold until early 1929.

descr: Serial No. 9043 L-head four-cylinder in-line engine, 176.7 cubic inches, 22 hp at 1600 rpm.
fact1: The car that brought auto travel to the masses, with over 15 million built 1908-1927.
fact2: By the '20s half the cars in the world were Model Ts.
fact3: Four-cylinder monoblock engine made use of detachable cylinder head.
fact4: Hand-built 1909-13 with initial price of $850. After assembly line method adopted in 1914, cost eventually dropped to $285.
fact5: Assembly line also led to black-only body color: Black paint faster dry time, and efficiency and savings in having only one color. Last few years of production saw color choices once spray lacquer paint available.
fact6: Produced with interchangeable parts — led to “shade tree” home mechanic.
fact7: Ford touted left-hand drive as feature for passenger (often a lady) to step out onto curbside.

descr: Serial No. 3317: Two-cylinder, four-stroke, opposed engine. 2690 cc, 10 hp at 920 rpm
fact1: Benz playing it safe with an outdated platform.
fact2: Was the largest car maker in the world at the time — 603 units produced in 1900.
fact3: This 10 HP 2-cylinder boxer was the popular model.
fact4: “Back to back” layout obsolete by 1901, showing Benz resisted change — felt 18 mph sufficient since it was still faster than the horse drawn wagon.
fact5: This car was displayed at 50th anniversary of the auto in Germany in 1936, then survived WWII firebombing of Dresden stored in a salt mine.
fact6: Car displayed in East German museum until fall of the Wall and then completely restored.

descr: Serial No. Z30003: Four-cylinder engine, 9236cc (573 cubic inches), magneto ignition. 60 hp at 1400 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — A survivor from the earliest days of racing.
fact2: FACTS — This was a state-of-the-art racer, capable of 75 mph. In fact, a sister car set the land speed record in 1902, at 76.08 mph.
fact3: STORIES — The side-saddle riding mechanic was kept busy during race: hand-pressurizing the fuel tank, spray oiling the “splash lubrication” motor, and lubricating the chassis. With the engine’s “open” lubrication, oil was everywhere and helped to make the (rear-only) brakes basically useless.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — The car has a frame and body made of wood, with ground clearance dictated in part by a large flywheel, and chain-drive. Dual chain drives driven by flex shafts running from a central differential. This was one of the earliest applications of pneumatic shock absorbers on all four wheels.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — The steering wheel features a kill-switch button to help slow the car in turns. The tube tires, of natural rubber, had cotton cord and were prone to failure (note rear tire debris-scrapers). The original pneumatic tires with pressures of 80-90 psi can’t be replicated today, so these are solid.

descr: Serial No. 1406V: Six-cylinder in-line engine, L-head, 5900cc, 28 hp, HP to WT Ratio: 136.75
fact1: Example of early “prestige” motorcar, favored by Heads of State (e.g. Czar Nicholas, King Alphonso XIII).
fact2: Built by French marine boiler company, with body by Mulliners Ltd. UK
fact3: Adopted the fully pressurized oil system that Bellville patented in 1897.
fact4: Could approach 60 mph and maintain it indefinitely.
fact5: Some cars documented to have gone 200,000 miles between motor overhauls.

descr: Serial No. 48: Four cylinder in-line engine, overhead valves pushrod actuated, 12.5 liters (775 cubic inches), 100bhp.
fact1: HEADLINE — A powerful and fast favorite of wealthy gentlemen racers (such as Charles Rolls and William Vanderbilt).
fact2: FACTS — This is one of half-a-dozen racers left from the early days of Grand Prix racing. After a racing career that spanned to at least World War I, it showed up outside New York City in the 1970s and was bought for $3,750 by a Schlitz beer heir. Mr. Collier bought the car in 2001 and put it through two restorations.
fact3: STORIES — The company got its start in the 1850s making artificial flowers; its stem-wrapping process later transformed electrical insulation. By 1887, Mors was making boats and steam tricycles, and by 1892 ICE autos. Its cars, especially racers, pushed technical boundaries, but innovation also strained the company and led to takeover by Citroen in 1907. This model was the last significant racing effort, and the last Mors car was built in 1925.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — This is the largest displacement motor at Revs — 12.8 liters with massive bore and long stroke. This large displacement was typical prior to the design breakthrough on the neighboring Peugeot. The engine bay features copper water jackets surrounding each cylinder, a cam compression release for cranking, and one of the uses of first pushrod-actuated overhead valves.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — The company slogan, quaint for a racing car, is “mors ianua vitale”, Latin for “death is the gateway to life”.

descr: Serial No. 764: Four-cylinder in-line T-head engine, 300 cubic inches, 58 hp at 1700 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — Considered to be America’s first sports car.
fact2: FACT — Large motor and well-balanced chassis made for a car built for racing right off the showroom floor.
fact3: STORIES — Company owned by the steel-making Roebling family (of Brooklyn Bridge fame) and built in Mercer County, New Jersey. Also in 1912: Family head Washington Roebling went down with the Titanic.
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — Muscular when compared to the Hispano–Suiza T-15, its sturdy caisson wheels were necessary to survive the bad American roads of the time.
fact5: INSIGHT — Capable of top speed of at least 70 mph with barely adequate brakes.

model: Type L3 Coupe de l'Auto Voiturette
descr: Four-cylinder in-line engine, double overhead camshafts, four valves per cylinder, 2980 cc (183 cubic inches), 90 hp at 2900 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — The forerunner of the modern engines we use today.
fact2: FACTS — This car won the  smaller Voiturette (“VWAH-ter-yet”) class of the 1913 French Grand Prix. (That same year, another Peugeot with the same engine design won the Indianapolis 500, by 13 minutes.) At the 1914 Indy 500, this car led 77 laps before finishing a close second to a Delage with an engine twice as large, and sporting a similar engine design. US reporters nicknamed this car “Le Bebe” (Baby) because of its size and light weight.
fact3: STORIES — Peugeot factory drivers Jules Goux (“SHEW-el Goo”), Georges Boillot (“SCHorge BWA-low”) and Paulo Zuccarelli, and draftsman Ernest Henry developed the first DOHC  architecture in 1912 as a secret project within Peugeot. The resulting engine was not immediately favored by Peugeot —  their own engineers called the skunkworks group “Les Charlatans” — and the company even had them vying with another outside design effort, headed by Ettore Bugatti. The Charlatans’ design won out, but even then Peugeot didn’t protect the rights to the design. As a result, the motor became the inspiration for new designs by many others, as seen elsewhere in the gallery.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — The double overhead cam architecture “breathed” more efficiently, providing greater horsepower than competitor’s motors of larger size. The radical ideas by “Les Charlatans” included monoblock construction, four valves per cylinder, and pentroof cylinder chambers with central spark.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — (1) The manifolds and other elements of the motor are original — however the iron block is not. The original block had been cracked and poorly repaired at some point. After three years and some $50K spent in trying to save the original black, Revs had it scanned and a sand printed mold was made to create two new Iron blocks; one of them is in the car. (2) The size of this engine is nearly the same as the Model T, though this has four times the horsepower.

descr: Serial No. B.N.209 M.N.5: Four-cylinder in-line engine, single overhead camshaft, 4483cc(273.7 cubic inches), 115 HP at 2800 rpm
fact1: HEADLINE — An example of Mercedes’ methodical approach to early auto racing.
fact2: FACTS — “BIS” is German for spare or alternate, and this was the support car to the Mercedes entry in 1914 at the prestigious French Grand Prix, where the factory team swept the first three positions.
fact3: STORIES — 250,000 French spectators watched in stony silence as the Germans won; three weeks later, WWI began. By 2014, this car toured Europe along with the winning car, to celebrate that victory.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — The motor’s advanced overhead valve design, adapted from aircraft engines, beat the twin-cam Peugeots.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — Also instrumental to the 1914 win was extensive pre-race testing, modifications to suit conditions and the first organized pit crew and signaling. Note the lap counter on the instrument bulkhead.

descr: Serial No. 65RB: Six-cylinder in-line engine, 7428 cc (453 cu.in.), 40/50 HP (48.6 R.A.C.)
fact1: Set a standard for automotive reliability, refinement & excellence.
fact2: “Silver Ghost” came from a silver paint/silver brightwork Barker-bodied prototype and the car’s uncanny silence.
fact3: This London-Edinburgh sporting chassis featured higher performance, with a top speed of 80 mph.
fact4: This chassis would have cost $7,000, with Kellner body another $10,000. As per Rolls-Royce advertising: “The quality will remain long after the price is forgotten.”
fact5: 6-cylinder motor in blocks of 3-cylinders each, with non-detachable L-head (valves on one side) and single carburetor.
fact6: Dual ignition: one distributor-based for starting with battery, the other magneto-based for running.

descr: Serial No. 13251: Six-cylinder in-line engine, T-head, dual valves, 477 cubic inches, 48 rated hp.
fact1: A status symbol with understated elegance
fact2: Pierce-Arrow was one of America’s “Three Ps” prestige manufacturers (with Packard & Peerless), and was the car of choice for American Presidents from Taft to Hoover.
fact3: Engine’s electric self-starter was invented and patented in 1911 by Charles Kettering, founder of Delco, who’d first replaced hand cranks on cash registers. First American auto use was on the 1912 Cadillac.
fact4: Engine compartment featured a built-in air compressor.
fact5: Extensive use of aluminum body panels.
fact6: Headlamps gracefully set into aluminum fenders was a P-A styling hallmark that ran all the way to the company’s demise in 1938.
fact7: Before producing automobiles at the turn of the 20th Century, George N. Pierce Company of Buffalo manufactured bicycles and birdcages.

descr: Serial No. 1003: Eight-cylinder in-line engine, double overhead camshafts, four valves per cylinder, 4816 cc, 140 hp at 3000 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — “The most advanced automobile in the word at the time” - Miles Collier.
fact2: FACTS — 1914 Indy 500 winner Rene Thomas (“Re-NAY Toe-MA”) put this car on the pole for the 1919 race at 104.7 mph, and was the first pole sitter over 100. The car led early but finished 11th, as Thomas backed off when two teammates crashed with problems due to tire/wheel issues on an extremely rough Speedway surface that hadn’t been used during World War I.
fact3: STORIES — Rene Thomas and friend Ernest Henry had collaborated on the design of the Delage that won the 1914 Indy 500. In late 1918, they convinced Ballot (“BA-low”) to tackle the 500, the world’s first major race after WWI, to burnish the Ballot brand. Before this, Ballot made motors — for cars, boats and planes — but never a complete car. In early 1919, Henry designed a car with an advanced 8-cylinder engine similar in design to the 1913 DOHC Peugeot. In just over 100 days, four cars were completed and sent to Indianapolis.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — (1) The underslung front suspension made the car low and sleek. (2) Photo records indicated several modifications made to the car during practice at the Speedway (handhold on cowling, steering column brace, bracing bracket between seats), and these were incorporated into the most recent restoration.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — (1) Originally thought to be the number 33 car (SN 1001), “witness marks” from comparison photos showed this to be the number 31 car pole-winning car (SN 1003) during 2016-19 restoration. (2) At conclusion of latest restoration, it was repainted using original formula of linseed oil-based paint applied with a brush, as it was done in 1919, with color carefully deduced from grey-tone matching of black and while archive photos with test colors.

descr: Serial No. V2911: Eight-cylinder, 90 degree vee engine, L-head 441.7 cubic inches, 95 hp at 2400 rpm. HP to WT Ratio: 40.78
fact1: HEADLINE — A powerful and beautiful American speedster from a builder of limos and hearses.
fact2: FACTS — Cunningham (no relation to Briggs) was rare among elite constructors, in fabricating bodies in addition to chassis, falling back on their tradition of building fine horse carriages in the 19th century.
fact3: STORIES — As a way of one-upping speed records that Packard made with an aircraft-powered car, Cunningham hired the same driver, Ralph DePalma, to drive a stripped-down stock Speedster chassis on a 98-mph 10-mile sprint on a Long Island board track. Less than a dozen Speedster chassis cars were built to honor the speed records that were set. This car may have been used to set those records (though documentation is inconclusive).
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — Seven of these “DePalma Speedsters” were roadsters, with an early boat-tail design and the largest production V8.
fact5: INSIGHT — The stripped-down Cunningham (maybe this one) that broke the Packard records copied the look of that Packard. And that Packard also inspired Briggs Cunningham’s rebodying of his Packard Speedster prototype.

descr: Serial No.?: Eight-cylinder in-line engine, double overhead camshafts, supercharged
fact1: HEADLINE — The dominant American racer of the 20s & 30s.
fact2: FACTS — Various cars with Miller/Offenhauser/Meyer-Drake motors won a total of 39 Indy 500s between 1922 and 1976.
fact3: STORIES — California carburetor and SOHC engine builder Harry Miller was asked to work on one of the first four DOHC Peugeot engines — and subsequently designed his own version! Miller machinist Fred Offenhauser acquired the business and the engine he improved on went on to dominate Indy car racing into the 1950s. Meyer-Drake was next to develop the design into the 70’s Turbo era.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — This car is a rear-drive version made for high-speed wooden board tracks, two-dozen of which saw fast, dangerous but short-lived success in America. The car is tall and thin — only 18 inches wide, the width of the motor — to slice through the air at high speed. The engine air intake is in the cockpit. It uses a centrifugal supercharger, mounted on the firewall, and pressurized carburation for more power.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — Regarded as one of the greatest racing engineers of the 20th Century, Miller left school early and never had formal engineering training. After bankruptcy and selling out to Fred Offenhauser, Miller became a partner with Preston Tucker in Tucker’s pre-WWII pursuits.

descr: Serial No. NR 516: Four-cylinder in-line engine, single overhead camshaft, four valves per cylinder, 2996 cc, 80-82 hp at 3500 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — A “Baby Bentley” racer for upper-crust privateer drivers.
fact2: FACTS — A true 100 mph-capable car, one of 18 factory cars built on shorter 9-foot chassis.
fact3: STORIES — Bentley guaranteed most of their production cars for five years, the Super Sport being the exception; it only had a one-year warranty, given its racing intent (still, generous for a racer).
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS - This Surbico (Surbiton Coach & Motor Works) body is a nautically-inspired  design, from its rounded front radiator, marine wind screen, and wood boat-tail rear to wind-swept fenders.
fact5: INSIGHT - W.O. Bentley was steeped in locomotive and aviation design, and his powerful and dependable engines reflected this.

descr: Serial No. 21642: Eight-cylinder in-line engine, twin overhead camshafts, two valves per cylinder. Roots-type supercharger, 1486 cc, 170 bhp at 8000 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — Correcting design mistakes made this car unbeatable.
fact2: FACTS — Robert Benoist (“Row-bear Ben-ooh-WAH”) won 5 of 7 races in 1927 and Delage placed 1,2,3 in both French and British GPs that year. Two years later, this car competed in the first Monaco Grand Prix. The first of five cars made, this is the only survivor that still runs.
fact3: STORIES — After the 1926 version of the car practically baked the drivers, the exhaust was moved to the other side and away from the driver and the supercharger relocated to the front of engine.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — An offset engine and drive shaft allowed a low, sleek design, and the car enjoyed excellent braking due to use of Hispano-Suiza licensed mechanical servo brake design. Motor features all roller bearings for low friction, and 20 timing gears. Despite the car’s exotic design, a hand-pressurized fuel pump was still used.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — (1) The front brakes use a jointed shaft actuated by a cable looping around a pulley. This reduces force on the front axle, and allows more modulation. (2) “Wings” behind front wheels are to deflect road debris without the drag of fenders.

descr: Serial No. 17181: Narrow angle (14 degree) V4 engine, two valves per cylinder, single overhead camshaft 2370 cc, 59 hp at 3250 rpm
fact1: HEADLINE — The first unibody production car.
fact2: FACTS — Lighter weight meant no dependence on a big motor to go fast. The (first production) V4 engine was perfectly capable of making this a performance car.
fact3: STORIES — A rough sea cruise crossing is said to have inspired Vincenzo Lancia to emulate the stressed panel hull of ships for automobiles, a radical departure from conventional ladder-frame chassis construction of the day.
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — Unibody allowed lower passenger compartment, and resulting driveshaft tunnel gave even more rigidity.
fact5: INSIGHT — (1) Only car in the Collection with a “sliding pillar” independent front suspension, as also seen on Morgan three-wheelers at that time. (2) Lancia Automobile founders Vincenzo Lancia and Claudio Fogolin formed the company while they were Fiat race drivers. Vincenzo came to Fiat as an inspector, then driver, after Turin Technical School (studying bookkeeping).

descr: Serial No. 11739: Six-cylinder in-line overhead camshaft engine, 7982 cc, 194 bhp at 3000 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — A grand touring car conveying prestige and exclusivity.
fact2: FACTS — (1) Meticulous engineering was evident in the H6C’s aircraft-based motor, with a jewel-like seven-main bearing crankshaft machined from a 770 pound billet. (2) A key feature is the use of mechanical servo-assisted brakes, first developed by Marc Birkgit for the H6 in 1919.
fact3: STORIES — H-S adopted their mascot from the French “Cigongnes” (“stork”) squadron in WWI, following the death of their top ace who’d had a stork painted on the side of his biplane.
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — All “Hisso” bodies were custom-built coachwork. This French Keller boat-tail theme is enhanced by rear fender wings that seem to be calved by the rear bodywork, suggestive of a speedboat.
fact5: INSIGHT — During WWI, H-S aircraft engines powered half the Allied air corps. With WWII, the company converted entirely to aero motors. With nationalization after the war, H-S was acquired by a French aviation company that continues to this day.

descr: Serial No. B8612-BA29C: Eight-cylinder in-line engine, single overhead camshaft, 298 cubic inches, 115 hp at 3600 rpm. HP to WT Ratio: 38.94
fact1: HEADLINE — A US supercar of the Roaring 20s.
fact2: FACTS — The powerful overhead cam straight-eight engine was developed with testing at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway in Stutz’s hometown.
fact3: STORIES — A 24-hour match race to a Hispano-Souza led to a 1928 Black Hawk Le Mans entry — by Hispano-Suiza’s CEO Charles Weymann! The 1928 Weymann entry placed 2nd at Le Mans. In 1929, five Stutzes and a Du Pont were the last American cars at Le Mans until Briggs Cunningham’s Cadillacs In 1950.
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — Harry C. Stutz came up with this “under-slung chassis” design early in his career, for the American Car Company.
fact5: INSIGHT — Stutz originally painted the car blue. Later it was repainted white with a red drive train. When the car was restored in 2007, it was painted in the same manner — first blue, then white; the inside of the hood is blue.

descr: Serial No. 36242: Six-cylinder in-line engine, single overhead camshaft, Roots-type supercharger, 7059 cc, 140 hp at 3200 rpm (200 hp with blower engaged).
fact1: HEADLINE — One of the most powerful sports cars of its time, at home on the road or the race track.
fact2: FACTS — The clutched supercharger blowing into the 7 liter engine’s pressurized carburetors gave in excess of 200 hp when engaged.
fact3: STORIES — This car was owned by Dorothy Paget, eccentric heiress to the Whitney family (of cotton gin and racehorse fame), who said she wanted the “fastest car in England”. She was the second-richest person in England, and helped “Bentley Boy” Tim Birkin bankroll the development of the rival 4.5 liter Blower Bentley.
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — SSK stands for Super Sport Kurtz, German for “Super Sport Short”. This design particularly excelled on twisty circuits and hill climbs.
fact5: INSIGHT — The last design project by Dr. Ferdinand Porsche before he left Mercedes-Benz to start his own engineering company.

descr: Serial No. 2349: Eight-cylinder in-line engine, twin overhead camshafts, four valves per cylinder, 420 cubic inches, 265 hp at 4200 rpm.
fact1: Cord acquired Duesenberg in 1926 to create the pinnacle of US custom automobiles; finished cars cost as much as $25,000 (over $450K in 2023 dollars).
fact2: With powerful engine design rarely seen outside of racing, this was the world’s most powerful production car, with a top speed of 116 mph, despite weighing over 5000 lbs.
fact3: Schebler duplex carburetor feeds to split aluminum manifold.
fact4: Engine features a mileage-activated chassis self-lubrication controller.
fact5: Custom body by LeBaron of Detroit features Dual Cowl Phaeton style, “Le Baron Sweep” and “bowtie” front bumper styling hallmarks.
fact6: Racing Duesenbergs won the French Grand Prix and the Indianapolis 500 in the ‘20s.

descr: Serial No. Serial No. YX5117, Engine No. YX5120: Six-cylinder in-line engine, single overhead camshaft, four valves per cylinder, three SU carburetors, 7983 cc (487.12 cubic inches), 250 hp at 3500 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — W.O. Bentley’s last effort to stay afloat, by taking on Rolls-Royce.
fact2: FACTS — The most advanced Bentley design to date, this was an intentional shift to a more-luxury platform. It also carried more of a limousine price tag — $9,000 (~$200K in today’s dollar).
fact3: STORIES — Ironically, while meant to challenge Rolls-Royce, this was the last Bentley before the company went into receivership and was taken over… by Rolls-Royce.
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — An immense two seater, with an eight-liter six cylinder motor in a 144-inch wheelbase — and this was a shortened version! The chassis incorporated a longitudinal reinforcing bar.
fact5: INSIGHT — This car was built in 1931 as a long-wheelbase four-door Saloon style, in two-tone grey on grey. It was then modified to a short-wheelbase two-door convertible, one of two such made by North London Corsica Coach works.

descr: Serial No. 55211: Eight-cylinder in-line engine, twin overhead camshafts, two valves per cylinder, Roots-type supercharger, 2970 cc, 135 hp at 5500 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — “A Bugatti Grand Prix car that has been house-trained” (-Tony Hogg, R&T).
fact2: FACTS — A supercharged Grand Prix engine made this ideal for sports racing — 99 mph in 1/4 mile and 0-60 mph under 13 seconds.
fact3: STORIES — Bugatti trademark “horseshoe”-shaped grills evolved from an egg-shape, an homage to Ettore’s father Carlo, a renowned furniture and jewelry craftsman who felt the oval was the perfect form.
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — Ettore’s son Jean Bugatti penned this body in his early 20s. It’s a cut above the rival Alfa Romeo 8C 2300; note the bright work (especially the swooping billeted front axle), the embossed highlights on body panels, and curves everywhere.
fact5: INSIGHT — (1) Cast aluminum spoked wheels not only looked good but were performance enhancements: Canted spokes pulled air over brake backing plates, which themselves were fresh drums when tires changed. (2) Wiring through body screws was a safety practice from aviation. - NOTE: 28 survive of 38 built (not “28 built” as on text panel).

descr: Serial No. 1930 Engine / 1933 Chassis Engine No. M-1011: Eight-cylinder in-line engine, twin overhead camshafts, four valves per cylinder, Centrifugal supercharger with intercooler manifold, 168.7 cubic inches, 200 + hp
fact1: HEADLINE — A testament to the heyday of American oval track racing.
fact2: FACTS — This car was raced successfully in various forms of American racing from 1930 to 1951.
fact3: STORIES — As a two-seater, Fred Frame raced this to 2nd place in the 1931 Indianapolis 500. (The following year, Frame won, in a Wetteroth-Miller.) Following its conversion to the single-seater see here, Frame raced it 1938-39, primarily in Sprint events. By 1940-41, Frame had sold the car and “The Dutchess of Racing” Dorthy Gruman ran it as part of her three-car West Coast team. The car was sold again in ‘41, when Gene Figone was killed in it in Santa Rosa. Post WWII, John Mosekian raced the car until 1951. Briggs Cunningham acquired it in 1973.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — This racer started as a two-seat Duesenberg chassis with a 91 cu. in. engine. Almost immediately, the first owner (Harry Hartz) enlarged the motor to 142 cu. in. In 1933, Fred Frame owned the car and had it converted to its current configuration: A single-seat chassis, the engine enlarged to 168.7 cu. in. and a Duesenberg “sidewinder” supercharger added. The engine is a pair of 4-cylinder motors bolted together with a common crank.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — (1) This is the only car in the Miles Collier Collection with no brake pedal. The Maserati-Whitworth hydraulic 4-wheel drum units are actuated by the handbrake outside the cockpit. (2) This is the last Indy 500 car built by Augie Duesenberg.

descr: Serial No. 2069-5491: Twelve-cylinder, 67 degree vee engine, 445.47 cubic inches, 160 hp at 3200 rpm.
fact1: More understated luxury than the Duesenberg.
fact2: Appealed more to corporate and government leaders than to movie stars.
fact3: Custom coach-built body by Dietrich of Detroit. Raymond Dietrich had earlier co-founded LaBaron coach works, responsible for the body of the adjacent Duesenberg.
fact4: Dual cowl windshield for rear seat passengers was true luxury feature; rolls down behind front seat.
fact5: Survived the Depression by appealing to a wider audience.
fact6: V12 engine was one way to differentiate in a limited market.
fact7: Smoothness and power of earlier Packard “Twin-Six” V12 motors inspired Enzo Ferrari to use V12s in his early Ferraris.

descr: Serial No. 2311241: Eight-cylinder in-line engine, double overhead camshafts, two valves per cylinder, Roots-type supercharger, 2336 cc, 142 hp at 5000 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — THE car to beat in the early 1930s.
fact2: FACTS — 8C 2300s won four straight Le Mans (1931-34) and also dominated the Mille Miglia and Targa Florio.
fact3: STORIES — (1) Luigi Chinnetti in an 8C 2300 won the 1934 Le Mans after a fuel tank leak was plugged throughout the race with chewing gum. (2) This car spent its early days in Florida. It was ordered by Henry Flagler’s son Harry, then owned by a Miami disc jockey, then early SCCA racer Bob Gegen, then Briggs. At one point it said to have been used as a gun carriage to hunt alligators in the Everglades!
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — (1) Designed by the brilliant Vittorio Jano, the 8C was Alfa Romeo’s go-to engine for Grand Prix, endurance and sports car racing. This body was by the Touring studio, on a  shorter “Corto” wheelbase chassis. (2) The pedal arrangement was different from typical cars — Left=clutch, Center=accelerator, Right=brake.
fact5: INSIGHT — (1) Two spare tires carried are due to differing front and rear sizes. (2) Two The motor’s dual four-cylinder blocks had a common crankcase and integral heads — so no head gasket to fail (but laborious valve work!).

descr: Serial No. K3025: Six-cylinder in-line engine, single overhead camshaft, 1086 cc, up to 120+ bhp at 6500 rpm. Roots-type Marshall supercharger. Four-speed E.N.V. preselector gearbox.
fact1: HEADLINE — A nimble, powerful and relatively affordable sports racer.
fact2: FACTS — Drivetrain featured a supercharger, and a novel pre-selector gear shift mechanism that allowed advance selection-then-activation by pedal when needed.
fact3: STORIES — This model began to challenge other European sports racers in noted events such as the Mille Miglia, where it won class in 1933, and Le Mans, where it placed 4th overall in 1934.
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — This was the largest of three racing models from MG.
fact5: INSIGHT — The pinched-off tailpipe was called a Brooklands Exhaust, for noise-reduction at urban setting racetracks; there’s also a resonator mid-pipe.

descr: Serial No. 1915189: Eight-cylinder L-head in-line front mounted engine, 323.5 cubic inches (5301 cc), 128 hp at 3400 rpm
fact1: Effort by young Chrysler company to come up with an innovation in aerodynamics and construction.
fact2: Flowing front end styling came from wind tunnel testing showing the cars of the day more aerodynamic running backwards.
fact3: Steel frame and cage construction and use of large panels of stressed steel led to car being 4-times more rigid than any other.
fact4: Moving engine forward allowed back seat to move ahead of real axle, giving more room in passenger compartment and better balancing out the weight of car.
fact5: Although an engineering marvel, its unconventional design, production delays and early quality issues turned off the public.
fact6: Chrysler hoped to sell 35,000 a year but sold only a third of that in ‘34. Continued slumping sales led to the plug being pulled in ‘37.
fact7: Just 212 of these CV Coupes were built; only a few survive.
fact8: Orville Wright one of several engineers involved in testing aerodynamic shapes for the Airflow

descr: Serial No. 48563: Six-cylinder in-line pushrod engine
fact1: HEADLINE — High water mark of pre-WWII Art Deco styling.
fact2: FACTS — Built as a show car, but its mechanical DNA was similar to the 1938 Le Mans winning Delahaye.
fact3: STORIES — A Revs restoration, with reproduced modern iridescent paint and color recalling original “fish scale”-enhanced paint.
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — Its Figoni and Falaschi coachwork appears to be a cloud floating on air with its fluid lines, while passengers “floated” in an interior of Hermes leather. A special “Three Olives” panel forming machine, dating to the mid-1800s France, was used to make large, complex curved shapes on this and other such cars.
fact5: INSIGHT — (1) Grill bumpers were changed and middle headlamp removed after a year (see exhibit photos). (2) A scissors-jack is incorporated under each side of the car.

descr: Serial No. 412036: Eight-cylinder in-line engine, double overhead camshafts, two valves per cylinder, supercharged, 2905 cc, 180 bhp at 5200 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — The most elegant, high-performance car before WWII.
fact2: FACTS — Supercharged twin-cam 8-cylinder engine was derived from the Alfa Romeo 2900 Grand Prix car.
fact3: STORIES — This car won the grueling Mille Miglia … in 1947! A similar car won the 1948 Watkins Glen Grand Prix.
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — Stylish Art Deco-inspired body by Touring of Milan, making use of their Superlegerra (Italian for “super light”) early space frame technology underneath.
fact5: INSIGHT — A sister car was featured in MOMO’s 1951 exhibit on excellence in auto design, along with BSC’s James Young Bentley.

descr: Serial No. Serial No. 85246: Six-cylinder in-line engine, vee-type overhead valves, aluminum cylinder head combining hemispherical combustion chambers with side camshaft, 1971 cc, 80 hp at 5000 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — A forward-looking vehicle that put young BMW company “on the map” as a sports car manufacturer.
fact2: FACTS — The relatively small but mighty engine, combined with a stiff, light tubular chassis allowed the car to far exceed performance expectations  — 100 mph from just 80 hp.
fact3: STORIES — Through reparations to the UK after WWII, the innovative hemi-head engine was acquired by Bristol cars and used in their AC sports car through the 50s.
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — The car’s flowing integrated roadster look was years ahead of its time.
fact5: INSIGHT — Motor featured an aluminum cylinder head with hemispherical combustion chambers and a single, block-mounted camshaft, with valves positioned at a wide angle for better flow, and giving it the look of a DOHC engine.

descr: Serial No. 33409938: Eight-cylinder in-line overhead valve engine, 320 inches (5245 cc).
fact1: HEADLINE — This car helped build the foundation of modern sports car racing in the US.
fact2: FACTS — Briggs Cunningham’s first attempt at building a sports car, albeit a “hot rod”, and a portent of his later efforts in designing and building race cars.
fact3: STORIES — This raced in events of the Auto Racing Club of America, created by C. Miles and Sam Collier prior to WWII. Post-war ARCA morphed into the Sports Car Club of America.
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — “Bu-Merc” name comes from Briggs’ melding of a 1939 Buick Century engine and chassis with a wrecked Mercedes SS body. The modified engine was shifted down and back, and the rear suspension features an early use of coil springs.
fact5: INSIGHT — This car ran in the 1948 and ‘49 Watkins Glen Grand Prix, finishing 2nd and 3rd respectively.

descr: Serial No. Serial No. 15: Twelve cylinders in vee formation, double overhead camshafts, two Roots-type superchargers 2962cc, 483 hp at 7800 rpm
fact1: HEADLINE — The apex of pre-WWII German racing technology.
fact2: FACTS — This was the last built of 15 W154 Silver Arrows, and it participated in the last race before WWII, on Sept. 3, 1939, in the Belgrade Grand Prix where it finished 2nd after leading from the start. In Grand Prix form, they were capable of over 180 mph; a streamline-bodied car did 246 mph in a speed run on the Autobahn.
fact3: STORIES — Post-war, it spent time in Romania, where it was run in hillclimbs, then Switzerland, then Japan, before Mr. Collier acquired it in 2006. Nine of the cars survive, this is one of two in running condition.
fact4: DESIGN & AESTHETICS — The engine and driveshaft were offset, allowing the driver to sit alongside the shaft, and lowering the car’s profile. The 1939 versions of the car had a flatter body and the improved W163 motor. Cylinders were combined in groups of three, in welded-on steel plate cooling jackets with non-removable heads.
fact5: NON-OBVIOUS INSIGHT — The two-tank fuel load of 62 gallons (at 2.8 mpg) was an exotic mixture of methyl alcohol, acetone, sulfuric ether and nitro benzine. Exhaust fumes could cause nausea, headaches and eye and respiratory problems. The drivers were covered with a tarp during refueling to protect their skin. The car now runs on 85% methanol and 15% nitro methane. The fuel is specially concocted for Revs and costs roughly $50 per gallon. It takes 30 minutes to start, in a 12-step process including a plug change. NOTE: The Revs website’s “before/after” photo shows a W154 at the Indy 500 (in 1947) — it was chassis #9, and not this car.

descr: Serial No. 016-I: Twelve-cylinder, 60 degree vee engine, single overhead camshaft, 1992 cc, 130 hp at 7000 rpm (140 hp with higher compression and alcohol fuel).
fact1: HEADLINE — The first racing Ferrari in America.
fact2: FACTS — Gioacchino Colombo designed this V12, inspired by 12-cyl. Packards and Cadillacs. A high-reving, lightweight silicon-aluminum short block with narrow bores to allow for capacity growth in future Ferrari engines through the years.
fact3: STORIES — This was the 8th of 9 built, driven as semi-works car by Luigi Chinetti in 1948. (Chinetti had won ‘48 Le Mans in a 166 MM.) BSC bought this from Chinetti when delivery of a Jaguar XK120 was delayed.
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — Had an “Inter” designation for its ability to run in F2 (without fenders and lights) or sports category (with).
fact5: INSIGHT — BSC finished second (to C. Miles Collier) in this car at 1949 Watkins Glen Grand Prix. Sam Collier was running first in the 1950 race when he crashed this and was killed.

descr: Serial No. 506111399: Eight-cylinder, 90 degree vee engine, overhead valves, 331 cubic inches, 160 hp at 3800 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — An American brute takes on the best of Europe, Part One.
fact2: FACTS — An impressive 10th overall finish in 1950 Le Mans with a lightly modified production car, dubbed Petite Petaud (“A Little Clumsy”) by the French.
fact3: STORIES — (1) Inspired by C. Miles Collier’s effort at Le Mans in 1939, Briggs Cunningham wanted to test the waters to see how an American car could do in a 24-hour road race. When his original blended “Fordillac” entry was rejected, he obtained two Cadillac Series 61s. This car was assigned to his friends from ARCA, C. Miles and Sam Collier. (2) The car suffered late-race transmission damage after avoiding a dog that wandered onto the track.
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — The Series 61 was Cadillac’s smallest and lightest model (at 3900 lbs!) with America’s most powerful engine, the Cadillac V8.
fact5: INSIGHT — The pair of Cadillacs were the first American cars with American drivers at Le Mans in over 20 years. [Charles Moran, Jr., Du Pont G, 1929 — also 5 Stutzes]

descr: Serial No. 506112964: Eight-cylinder, 90 degree vee engine, overhead valves, 331 cubic inches, 160 hp at 3800 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — An American brute takes on the best of Europe, Part Two.
fact2: FACTS — Briggs Cunningham took advantage of a rules loophole that permitted rebodying a production car. The resulting slab was dubbed Le Monstre by the French.
fact3: STORIES — (1) Briggs ignored Le Mans veteran C. Miles’ advice to stow a shovel. After the car went into sand bank early in the race, it took BSC 40 minutes to dig out and get going (note left-front damage in photo), to an eventual 11th place finish. (2) The car suffered worse damage a day before scrutineering, when co-driver Phil Walters was touring the course with the daughter of one the race organizers and ran up the tail of Briggs’ ‘49 Caddy support sedan then got rear-ended, when a horse cart stopped on the track. It took all night and an aluminum welding expert flown in from England to get the car ready.
fact4: DESIGN/AESTHETICS — Grumman Aircraft engineer assisted after-hours in coming up with a lower, lighter, wind tunnel-tested, aeronautical body over stock Cadillac chassis and lightly-modified motor.
fact5: INSIGHT — (1) The front badge is a winged Cadillac logo, reflecting the involvement of an aeronautical engineer. (2) In 2023, Le Monstre was one of a select group of past cars invited back to Le Mans to participate in pre-race festivities for the 100th anniversary of the race.

descr: Serial No. 131 SC: Four-cylinder in-line pushrod engine, 1090 cc, 60 hp at 5500 rpm.
fact1: HEADLINE — Modern sports car design comes to the Post-War world.
fact2: FACTS — Piero Dusio’s Consorzio Industriale Sportivo Italia (CISItalia) made a fortune outfitting the Italian army during WWII. Post-War he decided to make racers, commissioning Ferry Porsche (via Carlo Abarth) to help design an F1 car, and decided to also build a sports coupe. 100 of these 202SCs were built before the company was dragged down by the F1 project.
